title: Why does Eddie Van Halen tune his guitars down a half step from standard tuning? - Quora

response.answer_text: Many people do this. KISS did. I even know some local bar bands who do it. I believe Nirvana did it; sometimes more than a half step. It makes string tension slightly less so the strings are easier to push down, there’s s slightly bassier sound. You’ll see it more frequently in guitar only bands - no keyboard player to confuse. When i I was a kid guitarists couldn’t (or didn’t want to) play the Beatles “yesterday”. It was in F and had chords acoustic guitarists hate - F, Bb, etc. It wasn’t until years later I realized that the guitar was tuned a whole step lower. So while the guitar was playing easy chords; G, Bm, Em, C etc, what was coming out was F, Am, Dm, Bb. The song is MUCH easier to play in G, with a lot of nice big open chords.

Down tuning a half step does three things. First it makes it easier for the singer to hit the high notes. Secondly it makes the guitar a little easier to play with slack strings. But most importantly, it browns out the sound of the band just a little. Everything's just a bit mellow. I think Eddie was going for that more mellow effect. Most rock songs are in E or A, that's the nature of the guitar. For Van Halen and a ton of other 70s / 80s bands, they are in Eb or Ab. It's just a little more mellow. And I think it goes back to Jimi Hendrix, who influenced a ton of guitarists. Half step down is an “effect."
